decision_tree.1_check_cursor: Compare 'cursor' to stored cursor. SAME → STOP, nothing changed. Cost: ~200 bytes.
decision_tree.2_check_velocity: If 'velocity.velocity_alert' is true → this source is updating abnormally fast (possible zero-day or critical incident). Treat as high priority.
decision_tree.3_check_counts: If cursor differs, read 'counts'. flagged=0 AND new=0 → low priority, metadata only. You MAY defer.
decision_tree.4_fetch_digest: If flagged > 0 OR new > 0, fetch digest_url (~500 tokens). Read 'alert_count' and 'narrative'.
decision_tree.5_assess_alerts: alert_count=0 → no critical items. Log narrative, move on. Cost: ~500 tokens total.
decision_tree.6_fetch_latest: alert_count > 0 → fetch latest_url. Process 'buckets.flagged' first. Each flagged item has 'signals.suggested_action' (PATCH_IMMEDIATELY, VERSION_PIN, REVIEW_CHANGELOG, etc.) — follow it.
decision_tree.trust_note: Global digest 'signal_coverage' aggregates all sources — low values indicate many non-security sources (blogs, news) in batch, not extraction failures. For source-specific trust, check 'sources[source_id].signal_coverage' when changed:true. Security sources typically have 100% coverage.
decision_tree.signals_note: Items carry structured signals: severity (CVE/CVSS), release (version), incident (status), deprecation (breaking changes). All pre-extracted — no parsing needed.
